intro: Matricaria punctata, commonly known as the dotted chamomile, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disc florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its flowers are yellow with a central brownish disc, and they bloom from late spring to early autumn. Matricaria punctata is often found in dry, sandy soils and is used in traditional herbal medicine for its mild sedative and anti-inflammatory properties.
